ORG.description:
Defines an offset for subsequent code or data.
Address must be provided as a number (hex or decimal) or simple expression without any forward references.
Absolute addresses and labels may be used. 
The '$' symbol may be used in an expression to indicate current location.

DB.description:
Define byte.
Allocates a byte or multiple of them in memory.
Data can be defined as hexadecimal, decimal or binary number, or as an ASCII string.
Multiple numbers can be defined using the same label by separating them using a comma.
Numbers after the first one can be accessed using following syntax `LABEL+N` where N is an index of a number you want to access.

END.description:
Indicates the end of assembly module.
Anything after this directive is ignored.
If this directive is missing, end of file is considered an end of module instead.

EQU.description:
Defines a constant without occupying space in memory.
Every use of defined constant gets replaced by defined value.
Value cannot be changed later.
If you want to define a constant that can be redefined later use SET instead.

SET.description:
Defines a constant without occupying space in memory.
Every use of defined constant gets replaced by defined value.
Value can be changed later using another SET directive.

DW.description:
Define word.
Allocates two bytes (16 bits) or multiple of them in memory.
Data can be defined as hexadecimal, decimal or binary number, or as an ASCII string.
Multiple numbers can be defined using the same label by separating them using a comma.
Numbers after the first one can be accessed using following syntax `LABEL+N` where N is an index of a number you want to access.

BIT.description:
Define a bit address.
Defines a constant that can be used as a replacement of an address to a bit.

REG.description:
Define register symbol.
Defines a constant that can be used as a replacement of an address to an internal register or address to an internal memory.

IF.description:
Conditional assembly.
If the condition evaluates to TRUE (or not 0) instructions inside the IF block are assembled.
An IF block starts with the IF directive and ends with either ELSE or ENDIF.
If the directive ELSE is used to end the IF block then instructions between ELSE and ENDIF directives are assembled 
when the initial condition evaluates to FALSE.

ELSE.description:
Alternative conditional assembly.
Used in conjunction with the IF directive.
Instructions betwen ELSE and ENDIF directives are assembled 
when the condition of the IF directive preceding the ELSE directive evaluates to false.

ENDIF.description:
End of conditional assembly.
Used to denote an end of IF or ELSE directives.

MACRO.description:
Allows user to generate code snippets with parameters that can be used in similar way to standard mnemonics.
MACRO block has to be ended with either ENDM or MACEND.
Names of parameters are case sensitive.

```
NAME MACRO %PAR1, %PAR2
	INC %PAR1
	DEC %PAR2
	ENDM
```

ENDM;MACEND.description: Indicates an end of a macro.

INCLUDE.description:
Include a file.
Inserts source code defined in another file into the current one.
This directive is typically used to import files with macro definitions, variables, and declarations or definitions of subroutines.
It may also be used to import files with assembly code
